questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increased blurring of vision in both eyes for the past 4 months. She has tried using over-the-counter reading glasses, but they have not helped. She has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Current medications include lisinopril, insulin, metformin, and a fluticasone-vilanterol inhaler. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/70 in each eye. A photograph of the fundoscopic examination of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

IV acetazolamide is used to treat increased cranial pressure (ICP), e.g., due to pseudotumor cerebri. An increased ICP manifests with bilateral papilledema, flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages, and cotton-wool spots on fundoscopy. However, fundoscopic examination in pseudotumor cerebri would not reveal neovascularization.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye

Left image: Blurred disc margins (green overlay) with venous dilatation and tortuosity (blue overlay) and small hemorrhages (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible.

Blurred disc margins suggest optic disc edema. In intracranial hypertension, as seen in this image, optic disc edema is called papilledema.

Right image: Resolution of optic disc edema after treatment. Sharp disc margins and normal retinal vessels are visible. There are no hemorrhages.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical timolol is used to reduce the intraocular pressure of patients with open-angle glaucoma. Timolol acts by slowing visual field loss and optic disc changes. However, the fundoscopic exam of a patient with open-angle glaucoma would show notching of the neuroretinal rim, disc hemorrhages, and most specifically, cupping and pallor of the optic disc. This condition would not show neovascularization.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

An enlarged cup (yellow overlay) of the optic disc with thinning of the neuroretinal rim (green overlay) can be seen, especially evident in the temporal superior area of the optic disc (focal notching, indicated by arrow). Cupping leads to kinking of the blood vessels at the base of the cup (examples indicated by arrowheads).

This is a pathognomonic finding in glaucoma, predominantly caused by elevated intraocular pressure.

C) CORRECT:

Laser photocoagulation of the retina is used to treat proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), a long-term complication of diabetes that is evident in this patient's fundoscopic examination. PDR develops because chronic hyperglycemia results in the death of retinal microvascular cells and capillary dysfunction, with subsequent ischemia. Dying cells release vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), which promotes the growth of new fragile blood vessels (neovascularization) that hemorrhage easily and interfere with the transmission of light. Neovascularization can also cause retinal detachment and scarring. Laser photocoagulation helps reduce the progression of neovascularization and decreases the risk of vision loss. Strict glycemic and blood pressure control should be maintained in patients with PDR. Therapy with VEGF inhibitors may also be recommended, particularly in patients with significant macular edema.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral ganciclovir is used to treat cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. Fundoscopic findings of patients with CMV retinitis include a “pizza-pie” appearance of the retina (e.g., retinal hemorrhages, fluffy/granular white opacities around retinal vessels resembling cotton-wool spots, retinal detachment), but neovascularization is not typically found. Moreover, CMV retinitis manifests with floaters, photopsia, and/or visual field defects (due to retinal detachment).
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

Multiple retinal hemorrhages (red blotches, white outlines) and areas of retinal necrosis (fluffy white patches, black outlines) are visible in the central retina. In addition, the optic nerve (blue circle) is unsharply demarcated.

This combination of red hemorrhages and white retinal necrosis, referred to as the “pizza pie” (illustration) or “cottage cheese with ketchup” appearance, is characteristic of CMV retinitis, which most commonly affects immunocompromised individuals.

E) INCORRECT:

An ocular massage is useful for patients with acute retinal artery occlusion. Repetitive pressure to the sclera can dislodge emboli, leading to improved vision. Affected individuals show retinal whitening (due to ischemia) and narrow vessels with a red-appearing fovea centralis (i.e., cherry-red spot) on fundoscopy. Neovascularization is not typically found.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye

The fovea centralis looks dark red (cherry-red spot; green overlay) due to the transparency of this part of the retina lacking nerve fibres, causing the well-vascularized choroid to shine through. The surrounding retina is pale and opacified, indicating ischemic edema. Narrow retinal arterioles with box-carring (examples indicated by arrowheads) are also visible.

These findings are typical of acute central retinal artery occlusion.

F) INCORRECT:

Surgical vitrectomy is commonly performed in patients with retinal detachments, which can be a complication of neovascularization. However, fundoscopy would show a gray-colored, freshly detached retina, a retinal tear, or a detached retina floating freely in the vitreous body that moves with eye movement (affected individuals complain of floaters).
Image Description:

Fundus photography

A giant tear (blue overlay) with rolled margins (hatched overlay; the arrows show the path along which the retina has rolled up) is visible. The giant tear has caused retinal detachment (yellow overlay); the detached portion of the retina appears brighter than the attached portion of the retina.

The risk for retinal detachment is elevated in individuals with Marfan syndrome.
questions.hint: The fundoscopic image shows neovascularization of the optic disc and the retinal vessels.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive blurry vision in both eyes. His vision has not improved with the use of reading glasses. His blood pressure is 155/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows his visual acuity to be 20/80 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. A photograph of the fundoscopic examination of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A retinal detachment typically presents with unilateral, acutely decreased vision with prominent floaters and fundoscopy would be expected to show a region of crinkled retinal tissue in the detached area. This patient presents with chronic, bilateral blurred vision, and the neovascularization seen on his fundoscopic examination is not consistent with retinal detachment.

B) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension manifests with blurred optic disc margins (papilledema) and small hemorrhages on fundoscopy. Patients most often report significant headaches in addition to visual symptoms. Neovascularization of the retina, which is seen on this patient's fundoscopy, would not be expected in idiopathic intracranial hypertension.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye

Left image: Blurred disc margins (green overlay) with venous dilatation and tortuosity (blue overlay) and small hemorrhages (examples indicated by arrowheads) are visible.

Blurred disc margins suggest optic disc edema. In intracranial hypertension, as seen in this image, optic disc edema is called papilledema.

Right image: Resolution of optic disc edema after treatment. Sharp disc margins and normal retinal vessels are visible. There are no hemorrhages.

C) INCORRECT:

Open-angle glaucoma manifests with optic disc atrophy, notching of the neuroretinal rim, and disc hemorrhages on fundoscopy. These changes are caused by impaired absorption of aqueous humor through the trabecular meshwork and chronic increase in intraocular pressure. Patients typically present with chronic peripheral field deficits but retained central visual acuity. Neovascularization of the retina, which is seen in this patient, would not be expected in glaucoma.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a right eye

An enlarged cup (yellow overlay) of the optic disc with thinning of the neuroretinal rim (green overlay) can be seen, especially evident in the temporal superior area of the optic disc (focal notching, indicated by arrow). Cupping leads to kinking of the blood vessels at the base of the cup (examples indicated by arrowheads).

This is a pathognomonic finding in glaucoma, predominantly caused by elevated intraocular pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

A central retinal artery occlusion leads to sudden, unilateral loss of vision, not chronic, bilateral blurred vision, which is reported here. Typical fundoscopic exam findings include a pale retina and a so-called “cherry red spot” in the fovea. Neovascularization and tortuous vessels, which are seen on this patient's fundoscopic image, would not be expected in a central retinal artery occlusion.
Image Description:

Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.

Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

E) INCORRECT:

Dry macular degeneration is characterized by yellow deposits (drusen) on fundoscopy. Neovascularization, which is seen on this patient's fundoscopic image, would not be expected in dry macular degeneration.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye

There are drusen (yellow deposits, area marked by dashed blue circle) and retinal pigment epithelium atrophy (blue overlay).

Blue circle: optic disc
M: macula

F) CORRECT:

Diabetic retinopathy is a long-term complication of diabetes that occurs due to microvascular ischemia and osmotic damage secondary to the chronic elevation in serum glucose. The molecular pathogenesis of these changes involves intraocular sorbitol accumulation, which consumes NADPH and leads to oxidative stress. This oxidative stress ultimately leads to damage of the retinal microvasculature. The release of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) by dying cells promotes the neovascularization of the retina and optic disc that is characteristic of diabetic retinopathy.
questions.hint: The fundoscopic image shows neovascularization of the optic disc and the retinal vessels.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man reports a one-year history of blurry vision in both eyes. He has a history of uncontrolled type 1 diabetes, which was diagnosed when he was 16 years old. His most recent glycated hemoglobin level was 8.6% (reference range, 4.3–5.6).
On examination, his best corrected visual acuity is 20/40 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. The findings of direct ophthalmoscopy are similar in the left eye (figure) and the right eye.
Which one of the following treatments is indicated for this patient?

choices.text: Observation with repeat fundus examination in 4 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation with repeat fundus examinations is indicated in nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

More recently, studies have shown that intravitreal injections of anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (anti-VEGF) agents are very efficacious in preventing progression of proliferative diabetic retinopathy. These agents have therefore become first-line treatments. Ranibizumab and aflibercept — administered by intravitreal (not intravenous) injection — are approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for this indication.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitrectomy is indicated in persistent vitreous hemorrhage or tractional retinal detachment secondary to proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's history of type 1 diabetes places him at high risk for diabetic retinopathy. The figure reveals neovascularization of the entire optic disk, which is consistent with a diagnosis of proliferative diabetic retinopathy. Proliferative diabetic retinopathy is diagnosed when neovascularization is observed in the eye of a patient with diabetes. Neovascularization (the appearance of new blood vessels) may occur on the iris, retina, or optic disk and develops when chronic retinal ischemia stimulates the formation of abnormal capillaries.

Tight glucose control is encouraged in all patients with diabetes mellitus, given the multiple beneficial effects, including a reduction in the incidence of diabetic retinopathy. Even in patients with established diabetic retinopathy, tight glucose control can help slow down or prevent progression of the retinal changes. However, in patients with long-standing poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, rapid improvement in glucose control has been associated with worsening of diabetic retinopathy. Whether achieving good glucose control more slowly is beneficial in these situations is unclear, but many clinicians might opt for a slower rate of improving glucose in patients with established diabetic retinopathy.

In addition to glucose control, patients with established proliferative diabetic retinopathy need therapy directed at the retinal disease. Historically, the most effective treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy has been panretinal photocoagulation, in which multiple laser burns are scattered on the retina, avoiding the macula. This treatment improves the oxygen supply to the nontreated retina and reduces the risks of bleeding and blindness, but it may also reduce visual acuity.

More recently, studies have shown that intravitreal injections of anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (anti-VEGF) agents are very efficacious in preventing progression of proliferative diabetic retinopathy. These agents have therefore become first-line treatments.

• Ranibizumab and aflibercept — administered by intravitreal (not intravenous) injection — are approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for this indication.
• Intravitreal bevacizumab is used off-label for this indication and is much less costly. It is also used to treat neovascular age-related macular degeneration or macular edema associated with diabetic retinopathy or vein occlusion.

Key learning point: Treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy has historically consisted of panretinal photocoagulation but is now shifting to anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (anti-VEGF) agents.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravitreal dexamethasone is used to treat uveitis and macular edema.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes presents for routine follow-up of her diabetes. She has been feeling well since her last visit 4 months ago and reports no symptoms. She tries to adhere to a healthy diet and walks her dog twice daily for 20 minutes as her primary form of exercise. She has adhered to her medications, which include metformin and atorvastatin. She has also opted to take low-dose aspirin for primary prevention because of a strong family history of premature coronary artery disease. Her most recent glycated hemoglobin level one week ago was 6.7% (reference range, 4.3–5.6).
On physical examination, she has a blood pressure of 128/78 mm Hg, a heart rate of 86 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while she breathes ambient air. Her BMI is 29.9. Funduscopic examination reveals a few microaneurysms and cotton-wool spots bilaterally; they were not present at the patient’s last funduscopic examination one year ago.
The patient is concerned about the funduscopic findings and asks how these should be managed.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Prescribe lisinopril, with a target blood pressure of <120/80 mm Hg
Prescribe sitagliptin, with a target glycated hemoglobin level of <6%

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Advising against vigorous exercise is indicated in patients with severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy or with proliferative diabetic retinopathy until they are seen and evaluated by an ophthalmologist. However, this patient has mild-to-moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy; thus, vigorous exercise is not contraindicated, and walking a dog is not considered vigorous.

B) INCORRECT:

Uncontrolled hypertension is a risk factor for progression of diabetic retinopathy, but this patient’s blood pressure is already at the typical goal of <130/80 mm Hg. Tighter targets, such as <120/80 mm Hg, do not offer any additional benefit in preventing progression of diabetic retinopathy and would potentially be associated with adverse effects.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with type 2 diabetes should be closely monitored for the development of diabetic retinopathy. Monitoring usually involves a dilated eye examination every 1 to 2 years, typically by an ophthalmologist or optometrist. If the examination is performed by other members of the health care team and findings of diabetic retinopathy are noted, then the patient should be referred to an ophthalmologist for a comprehensive eye examination, close monitoring for progression, and (if indicated) consideration of additional interventions to avoid vision loss. This patient has developed retinal microaneurysms and cotton-wool spots, consistent with mild-to-moderate retinopathy, and should therefore be referred to an ophthalmologist.

Key learning point: Any evidence of diabetic retinopathy on funduscopic examination requires a complete eye examination by an ophthalmologist.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient is not at very high risk for cardiac disease but has opted to take aspirin for primary prevention, which is reasonable after a discussion of risks and benefits. Although her cardiovascular risk is low enough that she could opt to stop taking this medication, doing so would not affect her risk for vision loss. The presence of retinopathy is not a contraindication to aspirin therapy, as aspirin does not increase the risk of retinal hemorrhage.

E) INCORRECT:

Although uncontrolled diabetes is a risk factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy, the condition can also occur in patients such as this one who have well-controlled diabetes. A typical glycated hemoglobin target of <7% is reasonable, even in the presence of complications such as diabetic nephropathy. There is little evidence to support any benefit from a lower goal, and the additional medication burden associated with a lower target increases the risk of adverse effects.

The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

Diabetic retinopathy is a long-term complication of diabetes that occurs due to microvascular ischemia and osmotic damage secondary to the chronic elevation in serum glucose. This oxidative stress ultimately leads to damage of the retinal microvasculature. The release of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) by dying cells promotes the neovascularization of the retina and optic disc that is characteristic of diabetic retinopathy.

Key learning point: Diabetic retinopathy is characterized by retinal neovascularization and progressive vision loss due to chronic microvascular damage from longstanding hyperglycemia.
questions.hint: The fundoscopic image shows neovascularization of the optic disc and the retinal vessels.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the office because of increased blurring of vision in both eyes for the past 4 months. She has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of progressively worsening blurry vision in both eyes. He reports that his vision has not improved with reading glasses. His blood pressure is 155/98 mm Hg. On examination, his visual acuity is 20/80 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. A photograph of the fundoscopic examination of the right eye is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A retinal detachment typically presents with unilateral, acutely decreased vision with prominent floaters and fundoscopy would be expected to show a region of crinkled retinal tissue in the detached area. This patient presents with chronic, bilateral blurred vision, and the neovascularization seen on his fundoscopic examination is not consistent with retinal detachment.

B) INCORRECT:

A central retinal artery occlusion leads to sudden, unilateral loss of vision, not chronic, bilateral blurred vision, which is reported here. Typical fundoscopic exam findings include a pale retina and a so-called “cherry red spot” in the fovea. Neovascularization and tortuous vessels, which are seen on this patient's fundoscopic image, would not be expected in a central retinal artery occlusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension manifests with blurred optic disc margins (papilledema) and small hemorrhages on fundoscopy. Patients most often report significant headaches in addition to visual symptoms. Neovascularization of the retina, which is seen on this patient's fundoscopy, would not be expected in idiopathic intracranial hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Open-angle glaucoma manifests with optic disc atrophy, notching of the neuroretinal rim, and disc hemorrhages on fundoscopy. These changes are caused by impaired absorption of aqueous humor through the trabecular meshwork and chronic increase in intraocular pressure. Patients typically present with chronic peripheral field deficits but retained central visual acuity. Neovascularization of the retina, which is seen in this patient, would not be expected in glaucoma.

The molecular pathogenesis of these changes involves intraocular sorbitol accumulation, which consumes NADPH and leads to oxidative stress. This oxidative stress ultimately leads to damage of the retinal microvasculature. The release of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) by dying cells promotes the neovascularization of the retina and optic disc that is characteristic of diabetic retinopathy.

Key learning point: Diabetic retinopathy is characterized by retinal microvascular damage and neovascularization due to chronic hyperglycemia, leading to progressive, often bilateral, vision loss.
questions.hint: The fundoscopic image shows neovascularization of the optic disc and the retinal vessels.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 4-month history of worsening blurred vision in both eyes. She has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her current medications are lisinopril, insulin, and metformin. On examination, her visual acuity is 20/70 in each eye. A photograph of the fundoscopic examination of the right eye is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical timolol is used to reduce the intraocular pressure of patients with open-angle glaucoma. Timolol acts by slowing visual field loss and optic disc changes. However, the fundoscopic exam of a patient with open-angle glaucoma would show notching of the neuroretinal rim, disc hemorrhages, and most specifically, cupping and pallor of the optic disc. This condition would not show neovascularization.

B) CORRECT:

Laser photocoagulation of the retina is used to treat proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), a long-term complication of diabetes that is evident in this patient's fundoscopic examination. PDR develops because chronic hyperglycemia results in the death of retinal microvascular cells and capillary dysfunction, with subsequent ischemia. Dying cells release vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), which promotes the growth of new fragile blood vessels (neovascularization) that hemorrhage easily and interfere with the transmission of light. Neovascularization can also cause retinal detachment and scarring. Laser photocoagulation helps reduce the progression of neovascularization and decreases the risk of vision loss. Strict glycemic and blood pressure control should be maintained in patients with PDR. Therapy with VEGF inhibitors may also be recommended, particularly in patients with significant macular edema.

Key learning point: Laser photocoagulation is the treatment of choice for proliferative diabetic retinopathy to reduce neovascularization and prevent further vision loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical vitrectomy is commonly performed in patients with retinal detachments, which can be a complication of neovascularization. However, fundoscopy would show a gray-colored, freshly detached retina, a retinal tear, or a detached retina floating freely in the vitreous body that moves with eye movement (affected individuals complain of floaters).

D) INCORRECT:

An ocular massage is useful for patients with acute retinal artery occlusion. Repetitive pressure to the sclera can dislodge emboli, leading to improved vision. Affected individuals show retinal whitening (due to ischemia) and narrow vessels with a red-appearing fovea centralis (i.e., cherry-red spot) on fundoscopy. Neovascularization is not typically found.

E) INCORRECT:

IV acetazolamide is used to treat increased cranial pressure (ICP), e.g., due to pseudotumor cerebri. An increased ICP manifests with bilateral papilledema, flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages, and cotton-wool spots on fundoscopy. However, fundoscopic examination in pseudotumor cerebri would not reveal neovascularization.
questions.hint: The fundoscopic image shows neovascularization of the optic disc and the retinal vessels.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and HIV infection presents to the ED with sudden onset of blurred vision in his right eye. He denies pain or trauma. Laboratory studies from last week show a hemoglobin A1Cof 9.1% and a CD4 count of 520 cells/mm³. Vital signs are BP, 138/82; P, 86; R, 16; T, 36.9°C (98.4°F). Fundoscopic examination is shown. Visual acuity is 20/200 in the right eye and 20/40 in the left eye. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate empiric antiviral therapy for cytomegalovirus retinitis and refer to ophthalmology
Administer intravenous corticosteroids and refer to ophthalmology
Urgent ophthalmology consult for possible vitreous hemorrhage and retinal neovascularization
Urgent ophthalmology consult for possible retinal detachment
Diagnose HIV retinopathy and arrange routine outpatient follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus retinitis occurs primarily in patients with severe immunosuppression, usually with CD4 counts < 50 cells/mm³. This patient’s CD4 count of 520 and fundoscopy findings make an alternative diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are not indicated for this patient's condition and may worsen hyperglycemia. Corticosteroids are reserved for optic neuritis or autoimmune ocular inflammation.

C) CORRECT:

Correct — This patient’s retinal findings and visual loss are consistent with proliferative diabetic retinopathy complicated by vitreous hemorrhage. Urgent ophthalmology consult is indicated for definitive evaluation and potential laser photocoagulation or anti–VEGF therapy. A delay in referral can lead to permanent vision loss.

D) INCORRECT:

Retinal detachment typically manifests with flashes, floaters, and a curtain-like visual field defect, which is not consistent with this patient's symptoms and fundoscopy findings.

E) INCORRECT:

HIV retinopathy can manifest with cotton wool spots and microaneurysms, but neovascularization and acute visual loss are atypical. It is generally asymptomatic and often discovered incidentally on fundoscopic examination. In this patient, sudden, unilateral visual loss and extensive retinal hemorrhages are more consistent with an alternative diagnosis.
